I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
rupiah-denominated loan of up to Rp430 billion to Aetra Air Jakarta for the East Jakarta Water 
Supply Development Project in Indonesia.  
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
2.  Development  need.  Indonesia  continues  to  face  the  dual  challenges  of  low  water 
supply coverage and poor service quality. At the end of the last medium-term development 
program in 2009, only 48% of the total population had access to a sustainable source of safe 
water, and only about 26% had access to piped water.1 Following the current trajectory, the 
Government of Indonesia will fall short of reaching the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 
target of halving the proportion of those without access to safe drinking water sources by 2015.2 
3.  The development need is heightened by the combination of rapid urbanization and aging 
infrastructure.  The  urban  population  has  more  than  doubled,  from  56  million  in  1990  to 
approximately 122 million in 2010.3 Most public utilities, especially water companies, are not 
 
equipped to handle such drastic growth in urbanization. The proportion of the urban population 
served by piped water actually decreased from 36% in 1998 to 31% in 2008 (footnote 1). 
Jakarta, the largest city and capital, anchors an extended urban region4 with a population of 
more than 28 million, which is expected to grow to 35 million by 2020. However, Jakarta’s water 
supply network, originally built during the Dutch occupation, has not kept pace with the city's 
accelerated growth. Less than 65% of Jakarta's residents currently have access to piped water. 
The remaining urban population depends on individual wells, small-scale providers, or water 
vendors; often at high cost. The urban poor make up only 10%–15% of those with access to 
piped water and remain particularly vulnerable to the lack of access to safe water because of  
E. coli contamination of wells and groundwater, a main alternate water supply.5  
4.  According  to  Ministry  of  Public  Works  2011–2014  estimates,  a  total  investment  of 
Rp65.3 trillion is needed for Indonesia to achieve the MDG for water supply and sanitation by 
2015 (footnote 1, p. 29).6 As the funding capacity for the 2011–2014 investment program is 
limited to Rp28.5 trillion, the shortfall of Rp36.8 trillion demonstrates how public expenditure 
alone cannot sufficiently address the country’s water sector needs. 
 
5.  Concession history. Perusahaan Daerah Air Minum Jakarta Raya (PAM Jaya), a state-
owned enterprise, was established in 1977 to manage water supply and sewerage services in 
Jakarta. However, despite high tariffs compared with other Asian countries, PAM Jaya could not 
sustain an efficient management or investment program to meet the needs of residents. In

1997,  PAM  Jaya  granted  the  right  to  operate  the  city’s  water  supply  system  to  two 
concessionaires under two separate 25-year concessions; they will both terminate in 2023. 
Thames Pam Jaya (TPJ) was granted the concession for East Jakarta and PAM Lyonnaise 
Jaya (PALYJA) the concession for West Jakarta. Each concession was granted pursuant to the 
terms of a cooperation agreement. 
6.  Under  the  cooperation  agreements,  each  concessionaire  is  responsible  for  the 
production and distribution of clean water, including the expansion and maintenance of the 
water assets, for its respective assigned service areas in Jakarta. Responsibilities include the 
provision of water services to residential, industrial, and commercial customers, as well as 
management of billing and collections. Revenue collected by each concessionaire is placed in 
an escrow account. PAM Jaya receives a proportion7 as payment for its day-to-day monitoring 
and supervision of the relevant concession, and the concessionaires receive a water charge8 for 
each cubic meter of water produced.  
 
7.  The concessionaires have faced sizeable challenges. Indonesia was affected by the 
Asian financial crisis in the late 1990s and due to economic and political turmoil, PAM Jaya was 
unable to implement the tariff increases as agreed in the cooperation agreements. The resulting 
tariff freeze initiated a buildup of PAM Jaya accounts payable and strained the sustainability of 
the concessionaire operations. In 2001, PAM Jaya signed a restated cooperation agreement 
(RCA) with TPJ and PALYJA to try and resolve the tariff issue. The RCA laid the foundation for 
the creation of the Jakarta Water Supply Regulatory Body (JWSRB), which was intended to be 
an independent regulator in charge of supervising the concessions and reviewing requests for 
tariff increases on behalf of the governor of Jakarta and the Ministry of Public Works. 
8.  In 2003, for the first time since 1998, the average water tariff (charged to consumers) of 
Rp5,000 per cubic meter became higher than the water charge (paid to concessionaires) of 
Rp4,000 per cubic meter. In July 2004, the Jakarta City Council agreed to an automatic water 
tariff adjustment every 6 months over 5 years to allow PAM Jaya to pay accumulated water 
charge  arrears  to  the  concessionaires.  The  water  tariff  adjustment  formula  assumed  that 
increases in the water charge as well as any changes in the financial requirements of PAM Jaya 
and  JWSRB  would  be  fully  passed  on  to  consumers.  However,  the  adjustment  was  only 
implemented from 2004 to 2007.  
9.  Transfer  of  ownership.  In  2007,  TPJ’s  majority  owner,  Thames  Water  Overseas, 
divested 95% of its ownership9 in TPJ to Acuatico through a competitive bid process. Acuatico is 
a special purpose investment vehicle incorporated in Singapore. TPJ subsequently changed its 
name to Aetra Air Jakarta. 
10.  2012  master  agreement.  Following various further amendments of the cooperation 
agreement (from 2001 onwards),10 Aetra and PAM Jaya entered into a master agreement, 
signed on 5 June 2012 to address a number of fundamental issues with the East Jakarta 
concession. The master agreement came into effect in April 2012. One of the key principles of 
the master agreement is that Aetra will operate under the assumption of no overall average tariff

increase. In addition, the master agreement confirms the water charges to be applied to the end 
of the concession period, as well as a reduction in Aetra’s internal rate of return from 22.00% to 
15.85%. The parties intend to enter into a further amended and restated cooperation agreement 
(ARCA) in 2013 so that the cooperation agreement is entirely consistent with the terms of the 
master agreement. This will require numerous provisions of the cooperation agreement to be 
reviewed and harmonized. 
11.  ADB has been involved, through its nonsovereign operations, in the Indonesian water 
sector since 2007, when it approved a loan of Rp455 billion (approximately $50 million) to 
PALYJA, for  its  $121 million  capital  expenditure  program for  2008–2012.11 ADB’s  relevant 
experience makes engagement with Aetra a natural complement to ADB’s water strategy in the 
Greater Jakarta region. 
2.  Project Design 
12.  The East Jakarta concession provides water supply services through 340,000 residential 
connections  (both  piped  water  and  hydrants)  and  49,000  commercial  and/or  industrial 
customers in a concession area with a total population of 4.6 million.12 Approximately 740,000 
million liters of treated water are distributed daily through 5,929 kilometers of pipeline network. 
3.  The Borrower and/or Sponsor 
13.  Aetra is owned by Acuatico (95%) and Alberta Utilities (5%). Incorporated in Singapore, 
Acuatico is a leading investor, developer, and operator of water infrastructure projects with a 
focus on Indonesia and Viet Nam. It operates as a joint venture between Recapital Advisors 
(50%), a major Indonesian investment and financial advisory company, and Avenue Capital 
Group (50%), an asset management company based in New York. The Acuatico portfolio 
includes a 25-year water production and distribution concession in the Tangerang region in 
Indonesia,  a  30-year  water  supply  contract  for  a  Jakarta  development,  and  two  separate  
20-year water supply and distribution concessions in Viet Nam. 
 
14.  The four managing directors of Aetra have an average of 20 years of experience in the 
industry and retain strong relationships with all stakeholders in the Indonesian water sector. One 
of  the  directors  is  seconded  from  PAM  Jaya,  bringing  expertise  as  well  as  encouraging 
cooperation between Aetra and the grantor of its concession. Aetra management is supported 
by a team of 633 key operations staff with an average of 17 years of industry experience.13 
Leveraging the strength of management and staff expertise, Aetra has maintained profitability 
every year since the management team was appointed, following the change of ownership of 
the  concessionaire  in  2007.  Management  is  overseen  by  a  five-member  board,  which 
supervises company strategy and management. The board includes experienced water sector 
professionals from Southeast Asia as well as key personnel from Acuatico to provide financial, 
legal, and engineering expertise.

B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
15.  Impact. The project supports the government’s effort to meet the MDG 7 target for water 
supply by increasing access to improved drinking water sources through investment in critical 
water infrastructure, helping the people of Indonesia gain access to more stable and affordable 
piped water supply. The commercial success of this concession is also expected to attract 
private sector participation in water concessions in other cities across the country.  
 
16.  Meeting  the  impact  targets  will  require  improvements  in  the  overall  regulatory 
environment for the water sector in Indonesia as well as public sector investment to provide 
―last-mile connectivity‖ for low-income households that currently rely on relatively expensive 
water supplied by vendors.14 ADB nonsovereign and sovereign operations15 have collaborated 
to  build  JWSRB  capacity  (para.  23)  and  expand  access  to  the  urban  poor  (para. 29). 
Coordination  with  ADB  public  sector  efforts  to  improve  the  regulatory  framework  in  the 
Indonesian water sector and facilitate connectivity is essential to achieving the project’s impact. 
 
17.  Outcome. The outcome will be improved water provision in East Jakarta by a more 
financially viable Aetra. 
 
18.  Output. The output will be the completion of the 2013–2017 capital expenditure program 
for Aetra, involving (i) the rehabilitation and upgrading of production facilities; (ii) the expansion, 
rehabilitation,  and  maintenance  of  distribution  networks;  and  (iii)  improved  corporate 
environment and social safeguard standards. The investment is expected to add 45,000 new 
residential  water  connections,  benefiting  both  individual  households  and  communities  with 
access to a shared water connection. 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
19.  The  project  directly  supports  infrastructure  development,  one  of  the  core  areas  of 
Strategy 2020.16 The project targets solving critical underinvestment problems in the operation 
and maintenance of key urban infrastructure assets to facilitate more sustainable urbanization.  
The project is fully consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2012–2014 for Indonesia 
through its first pillar of inclusive growth, which includes support for catalytic projects to improve 
access to water supply in selected cities and towns in Indonesia.17 It supports government 
efforts  to  expand  access  to  improved  water  supply  services,  particularly  for  poor  and 
underserved populations, and strengthens local government capacity for public service delivery. 
The  project  is  also  in  line  with  the  country  partnership  strategy’s  focus  on  enhanced 
collaboration between ADB's sovereign and nonsovereign operations to improve the business 
climate  and  engage  in  capacity  building  to  promote  bankable,  scalable  public–private 
partnership projects. 
2.  Consistency with the Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020 
20.  The project promotes development of sustainable water supply and is consistent with 
ADB’s Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020, which identifies increased efficiency in water use 
and greater private sector partnership as priority solutions in response to the huge unmet water

investment reaching $25 billion by 2020, of which private sector participation will provide more 
than $500 million per year. 
 
3.  Previous Operations and Lessons  
21.  On 31 August 2007, ADB approved a loan of Rp455 billion (approximately $50 million) to 
support PALYJA in its $121 million capital expenditure program for 2008–2012, the third 5-year 
period of the water concession. In 2011, PALYJA’s performance was limited by a tariff freeze 
and  the  unavailability  of  new  sources  of  bulk  water.  However,  through  prudent  cash 
management and operating efficiency, PALYJA’s 2011 financial and operating performance 
remained positive, and outstanding debt servicing capacity for the ADB debt remains strong. 
  
22.  ADB’s financing of PALYJA illustrates the importance of ADB engaging with JWSRB and 
PAM Jaya to ensure continuous dialogue between the two entities to facilitate the resolution of 
disputes over the cooperation agreement. ADB has approved a capacity building opportunity for 
JWSRB to  enhance  its  effectiveness  and facilitate the  performance of  its functions  as  an 
independent regulator in the Jakarta water sector. This is expected to considerably enhance the 
success of the project.19

F.  Projected Financial and Economic Performance 
24.  The project is financially viable because the expected financial internal rate of return is 
higher than the weighted average cost of capital. The project is economically sustainable with 
an economic internal rate of return higher than the social discount rate of 12%.21

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
25.  The assistance will be a corporate unsecured loan to Aetra of up to Rp430 billion 
(approximately $44.7 million) without government guarantee.

B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
26.  ADB’s  involvement  in  the  project  is  justified  through  (i)  diversified  financing—Aetra 
currently has access to financing from local commercial banks, and ADB participation will help 
Aetra diversify its sources of local currency financing; and (ii) public–private partnerships—the 
project is an excellent example of the complementary value offered by ADB’s private and public 
sector  operations. While  the  private  sector  investment  will  help  ensure  Aetra  achieves  its 
technical and financial targets without tariff increases, ADB as a whole brings value as follows: 
 
(i)  Improving “last-mile” connections. While the investment in water treatment is 
essential to complement existing public sector efforts22 to increase the quality, 
quantity, and reliability of Jakarta’s raw water supply through investments in West 
Tarum Canal and Bekasi siphon, public investment in the distribution network is 
also needed, especially for poorer areas of the city. ADB sovereign operations 
will provide capacity development technical assistance (TA) in 2013 to introduce 
programs similar to those implemented by local governments in other Indonesian 
cities, and similar to the Tubig para sa Barangay (Water for the Community 
Program) of Manila Water in the Philippines. The TA will provide an additional 
avenue for Aetra to reach the urban poor.23  
 
(ii)  Enhancing the efficiency of the independent regulatory body. In 2012, ADB 
nonsovereign and sovereign operations successfully used regional TA funds to 
build the capacity of JWSRB through dialogue with regulators in Manila. The plan 
involves twinning JWSRB with other regulators in Southeast Asia and outside the 
region  to  facilitate  the  knowledge  and  experience  exchange.  The  twinning 
program would give JWSRB the opportunity to adopt or learn from management 
models that have achieved success in other similar concession areas. 
 
27.   Through its collaborative approach, the project will demonstrate how public–private 
partnerships can help water projects in Indonesia remain commercially and technically viable, 
and  can  benefit  from  ongoing  regulatory  reform.  This  assistance  complements  ADB’s 
involvement in PALYJA. ADB’s holistic engagement in Jakarta will allow ADB to better observe 
and raise issues with the government on key policy challenges facing the evolving Indonesian 
water  sector.  Moreover,  combined  with  experience  across  ADB, the  project  will  help  ADB 
meaningfully contribute to dialogue on water sector management and regulation throughout 
Southeast Asia. 
C.  Risks 
28.  Raw water risk. Aetra’s water supply originates from the Jatiluhur reservoir and flows 
through West Tarum Canal. As such, Aetra is exposed to possible water supply interruptions 
through (i) inadequate maintenance and repair of the canal and associated pumping stations; 
and (ii) lack of management capacity of Perum Jasa Tirta II, the canal operator. To date, overall 
raw water availability has been adequate and the risk of short-term supply interruptions is 
mitigated through  ADB’s  public  sector  assistance  on  improving  integrated  water resources 
management in the Citarum Basin. One such project, ADB’s construction of the Bekasi siphon 
(to be completed in 2013), will markedly improve Aetra’s raw water supply quality by diverting

flows from Bekasi River away from the canal. This will improve Aetra’s water quality and lower 
associated treatment costs.  Aetra does not have direct water supply contract with Jatiluhur 
reservoir operator Perum Jasa Tirta II; its raw water is supplied by Perum Jasa Tirta II under a 
five yearly renewable contract with Pam Jaya (due for renewal in December 2016). The lender’s 
technical advisor considers that a failure by PAM Jaya to supply bulk water to Aetra is highly 
unlikely given the social and political importance of a steady water supply for Jakarta. 
 
29.    Regulatory risk. Since Aetra and PAM Jaya have neither the authority nor control over 
increases in the levels of the water tariff, the master agreement fixes the water tariff schedules 
at  their  currently  agreed  levels  for  the  remainder  of  the  concession  period.    The  master 
agreement also provides for an agreed set of financial projections that allow for Aetra to operate 
sustainably.  ADB has identified that the financial projections need to ensure a clear linkage 
between all financial statements and therefore ADB will enter into the facility agreement only 
after it is satisfied that appropriate revisions have been made to the financial projections.  In 
light of the multiple amendments to the cooperation agreement to-date, Aetra and PAM Jaya 
are scheduled to execute the ARCA in 2013 which will consolidate the cooperation agreement 
so that it is entirely consistent with the master agreement. The master agreement stipulates the 
nature of the amendments to be expected. ADB’s review of the ARCA prior to its execution will 
be a condition of ADB’s second loan disbursement.   
 
30.  Revenue risk. Under the master agreement, Aetra must operate within the constraint of 
water tariff schedule remaining fixed for the remainder of the concession period.  This requires 
AETRA to achieve a higher average tariff from its customer base via customer reclassifications 
and to progress with NRW reductions, in order to grow its revenues.  NRW remains a key issue 
for Aetra.  The lender’s technical advisor also notes that Aetra has robust systems in place to 
allow for early detection of leaks and related repair.  Under the new operating principles agreed 
to in the master agreement, both Aetra and PAM Jaya agree that Aetra can achieve long-run 
financial and operational viability under the current arrangements.

Aetra’s liquidity position could be adversely affected, especially in 2015 when a large portion of 
its debts will come due.  To minimize the risk of a tight liquidity situation Aetra can consider 
raising additional debt (from its current base of modest leverage) or conserving cash by limiting 
dividend payouts.

33.   Execution risk. The four managing directors of Aetra have an average of 20 years of 
experience in the industry and retain strong relationships with all stakeholders in the Indonesian 
water sector, including PAM Jaya itself.  After Acuatico took over the concessionaire from 
Thames Water, Aetra has reversed its accumulated deficit into a surplus.  There is continuity 
with the staff that performs operations and maintenance services, as they are carried out in-
house by experienced technicians who have been with the concessionaire from the time when 
Thames Water was Aetra’s primary owner.

9 
 
34.   Portfolio risk rating.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
35.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified as 
category B for environment. Aetra’s past and present performance on environmental and social 
safeguards  was  audited  and  found  satisfactory.  Aetra  will  take  actions  stipulated  in  the 
corrective action plan in the audit report, including improvement of its environmental and social 
management system (ESMS) to comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. Aetra will 
confirm to ADB annually its compliance with national laws and the ESMS, and provide reports 
accordingly. The project is classified as category C for involuntary resettlement and indigenous 
peoples. It does not involve land acquisition or relocation of inhabitants since rehabilitation of 
existing connections and development of new connections will be along the roadsides or rights-
of-way. Nevertheless, Aetra has reviewed the land acquisition history of the proposed sites to 
ensure that national requirements were met, and ADB’s requirements were complied with. 
Furthermore, as the project is located in East Jakarta, where no indigenous peoples live, no 
impact on indigenous peoples is foreseen. 
 
36.  ADB  assesses  the  institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  Aetra  to  manage  the 
project’s social and environmental impacts as adequate.24 Measures to benefit new connection 
households, including benefits to women through reduced water collection times and improved 
health conditions, are incorporated in the project design in accordance with ADB’s Policy on 
Gender and Development (1998). ADB will ensure that the investment documentation includes 
appropriate provisions requiring Aetra to comply with national labor laws and take specific 
measures (including contractors) in relation to the internationally recognized core labor standard 
for  the  ADB-financed  portion  of  the  project,  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Social  Protection 
Strategy.25 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
37.  Aetra was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date), and 
policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism (2003).26 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB 
requires Aetra to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls following 
international  best  practice  standards  for  the  purpose  of  preventing  corruption  and  money 
laundering activities and the financing of terrorism; and to covenant with ADB to refrain from 
engaging in such activities.   
                                                
24  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy; Safeguards and Social Dimensions Summary (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
25  ADB. 2001. Social Protection Strategy. Manila. 
26 The Financial Action Task Force classifies Indonesia as a strategically deficient jurisdiction in relation to combating 
money laundering and the financing of terrorism. The project team was mindful of this when conducting its integrity 
due diligence, which did not disclose any significant integrity risk.

10   
C.  Investment Limitations 
38.  The proposed loan is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and single-
project exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
D.  Assurances 
39.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 27  the 
Government of Indonesia’s no objection to the proposed assistance to Aetra will be obtained. 
ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, 
following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  rupiah-
denominated loan of up to Rp430,000,000,000 to Aetra Air Jakarta for the East Jakarta Water 
Supply Development Project in Indonesia from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with such 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and 
as may be reported to the Board.

  Millennium Development Goal 7, Target 7.c, calls on countries to "Halve, by 2015, the proportion of people without

Although the MDG target is for 2015, Indonesia’s achievement of this target will likely be delayed. 
b  Access to safe drinking water is measured by the proportion of the population using an improved drinking-water 
source. An improved drinking-water source is defined as one that, by nature of its construction or through active 
intervention, is protected from outside contamination, in particular from contamination with fecal matter (World 
Health Organization–United Nations Children’s Fund: Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation. 
http://www.wssinfo.org/definitions-methods/introduction/).  Improved  drinking  water  sources,  according  to  the 
Government of Indonesia, include piped water, rainwater, water sourced from protected wells and protected springs 
greater than 10 meters from septic tanks (Statistics Indonesia. http://www.bps.go.id/eng/menutab.php?tab=1)
